item.title: Initial ESXi config from command-line
item.description: I have collected a number of cool commands that can manage ESXi over the years. The list below is based on ESXi 6.7. The commands below assume you have logged into the ESXi server via SSH as the root user. Additionally, these commands were run on a newly installed server with 4x NICs. The goal of this section: Add two NICs for Management (vSwitch0) Add two NICs to a new vSwitch for all data traffic (NFS, customer data, etc)

item.title: Ubuntu Network config using netplan
item.description: IP Address Examples Static IP Address In this example, we have a static IP address assigned to eth0 with a list of DNS nameservers separated by commas. /etc/netplan/template.txt # -------------------------- # Static IP Address Example # -------------------------- network: version: 2 renderer: networkd ethernets: eth0: dhcp4: no dhcp6: no addresses: [172.16.1.999/24] gateway4: 172.16.1.1 nameservers: addresses: [172.16.1.5,172.16.1.8] DHCP IP Address In this example, we are assigning a DHCP address to eth0.

About Me I am Ron Kelley - Team Leader, Mentor, Infrastructure Architect, and hard-core Technology Nerd. My passion lies in the entire infrastructure stack - from hardware, to software, to firmware. I love building out high-performance compute environments ranging from single-host virtualization servers to multi-rack configurations that span multiple networks, compute farms, and storage systems. A self-starter by nature, I enjoy deploying virtualization clusters, installing Linux via PXE, configuring IPSec tunnels on pfSense firewalls, setting up haproxy and nginx app stacks, configuring LXD containers, and lots of other cool stuff.
